Limited resources: Introducing new waste management practices and infrastructure can be expensive, and the community may not have the necessary funds to implement these changes.
Resistance to change: Some members of the community may resist the changes required to achieve zero waste, such as changing their habits or paying more for waste disposal.
Inadequate education: There may not be enough education and awareness about the importance of waste reduction and recycling, which can hinder the success of the zero waste movement.
Insufficient support: The community may not have the necessary support from local government or businesses to make the zero waste movement a reality.
Difficulty in measuring success: It can be challenging to measure the success of the zero waste movement, as it requires tracking changes in waste production and disposal habits over time.
